text:
today on hot thai kitchen we are making mango and 
sticky rice so what we have welcome to hot Thai

kitchen today's episode is going to be extra fun 
because we are remaking the most popular Thai

dessert on hot Thai kitchen and that is mango and 
sticky rice but this time around I'm also going

to show you how you can still enjoy this dessert 
even if you can't find any good fresh mango but

first let's talk about the name of the dessert 
mango and sticky rice in Thai is called Kao niew

mamuang kao means rice niew is sticky and mamuang
is mango so that's pretty straightforward there

are four components to this dessert first we've 
got the sweet coconut sticky rice we've got the

salted coconut sauce crispy mung beans which are 
going on top and then finally of course mango

our hero let's take a look at our ingredients 
for the sweet coconut sticky rice we have 1 cup

white sticky rice often labeled as glutinous 
white rice or Thai sweet rice 2/3 of a cup of

coconut milk 1/2 a teaspoon of salt 1/2 a cup of 
sugar for the salted coconut sauce 1/2 a cup of

coconut milk 1/4 teaspoon of salt 1 teaspoon of 
rice flour and 1 tablespoon of water apart from

that you also need 2 tablespoons of mung beans and 
of course our mango let's first deal with our rice

we have to soak the rice but before we soak it we 
have to give it a really really good washing so

I've got my rice here and I'm going to wash it 
in cold water just kind of be be vigorous with

it and then you can see how cloudy the water is 
getting now and that's basically the excess star

said we're trying to get rid of so we're going 
to pour this off and then repeat until the water

runs clear which is going to be about 5 times now 
you may be wondering why are we washing the rice

so obsessively and the reason is that think of 
these excess star just loose flowers just hanging

around the grains when we go to pour the syrup 
into our rice which is what we're going to do

it's going to kind of gum up the rice a little 
bit which is not a desired characteristics of

sticky rice for this dish we're not trying to make 
creamy rice pudding a risotto in which case this

start is exactly what we're we need but we want 
to macerate the rice inoculated with sweet syrup

while still maintaining individual integrity 
of the rice so that's why we want to get rid

of as much of this stuff as possible see if I'm 
right there see how much clearer it is you can

see my hand through the water and that's kind 
of what you're going for and then we're gonna

let this soak in cold water for at least four 
hours or up to overnight I like to do it just

overnight this then I don't have to worry about 
it and then we'll come back when that's done so

the rice has been soaking now for overnight I 
did this yesterday and then we're just gonna

drain it very simply just drain it but you want 
to make sure you are not too aggressive with the

rice at this point because once the rice has been 
soaked it's very brittle if you're too hard on it

the grains will actually break quite easily just 
want to make sure you drain it off really well so

you want to shake it a couple of times because if 
you've got too much residual water when you go to

steam it especially on a steamer rack type thing 
the residual water will make its way down to the

bottom and get trapped and then make the bottom 
layer of the rice mushy so you want to make sure

it's all gone I usually just leave this sitting 
while I'm doing other things to get it ready so

let's talk about steaming apparatus for me I'm 
going to use this traditional bamboo cone steamer

but you can also use other kinds of steamer like 
this one right here and this is massive but you

can use some rice cookers come also with a steamer 
rack insert anything that will steam will do and

what you need basically is to line because the 
holes are baked and the rice will go through

if you don't put anything on it line the rack 
we just use a muslin I just bought this muslin

and so the edges and then put the rice in the 
middle fold the edges over so that when you're

done when the rice is done you can just grab this 
and the whole thing out now this is important if

your steamer is small don't put the rice over the 
entire rack make sure you've got some room around

the edges otherwise you trap the steam if you 
leave some room the steam can come up and cook

the rice or surround the rice so it will cook more 
evenly okay so just be aware of that so my water

is boiling now I'm going to steam my rice over 
rapidly boiling water for 30 minutes because I'm

using the bamboo steamer halfway through I'm 
going to come and flip it but if you're using

just a steamer rack just leave it 25 to 30 minutes 
just leave it all the way through you'll be fine

so let's quickly make the coconut syrup for our 
rice to macerate in and it's really pretty darn

simple so in a pot just going to combine our 
coconut milk some sugar half a teaspoon of

salt now don't stir this for any length of time 
don't reduce it or anything as soon as the sugar

is dissolved and that's that's done because you 
want to preserve the total amount of liquid so

our rice has enough liquid to absorb or it'll 
be too dry oh and you also want to make sure

that this is done before the rice is finished 
because as soon as the rice is done you won't

you need to use this right away I'm pretty much 
all dissolved now so I'm just gonna turn it off

and then I'm gonna put a lid on it to keep it warm 
so when I'm ready to use it it hasn't gone cold

so the sweet and salty combination is becoming 
quite trendy lately we've got you know salted

caramel and bacon and chocolate and all sorts of 
things well Thai people have been doing the sweet

and salty thing for quite some time now and a 
lot of times the salty component is just a simple

salted coconut sauce and that is what we're gonna 
make right now so I've got half a cup of coconut

here and I'm going to thicken it using some rice 
flour and it's just a teaspoon of rice flour and

I'm going to add some water and just dissolve 
it just until there's no more clumps and if you

need to add you want to make it a little thicker 
later you add more starch you want to dissolve it

in more water again never add dry starch to hot 
liquid okay so now I'm going to pour that in so

I've got just a quarter teaspoon of salt and 
I'm going to bring that to a boil just until

the liquid starts bubbling and all we're trying 
to do is bring the rice flour to the temperature

where it can reach its maximum thickening power 
and if your mixture is already bubbling you know

that you're there and you want to stir it all the 
time because starch has a tendency to settle at

the bottom when the mixture is still cold now my 
bubbles are up and you can see that my rice flour

has thickened a little bit if you want you can 
make it thicker but I don't really it'll thicken

a little bit more as it cools down I don't like 
the sauce to be too thick but you don't want it

completely thin that it just kind of let all 
over the place when you put it on so my rice

just finished and then I'm gonna flip directly 
into the bowl and then immediately I'm going to

pour my syrup over and I'm going to give it a good 
stir now I know it looks soupy now but give it a

minute and then what not a minute 40 minutes to 
be exact and all the liquid will be absorbed into

the rice you want to start and make sure there's 
no clumps of rice that will prevent absorption

okay and then working quickly I'm going to cover 
it with foil top it off with something heavy and

we'll let this sit for 20 minutes during which 
time the rice is going to absorb all the liquid

and become plump and sweet and scrumptious and 
then the coconut oil in the coconut milk will coat

the rice making it smooth and silky mmm it's going 
to be very good now you may have noticed that I

worked pretty quickly because I want to make sure 
this mixture stays hot because if it's cold the

rice won't absorb the liquid quite as well so as 
soon as the rice is done work on this right away

make sure your syrup is still warm it doesn't have 
to be piping hot but it shouldn't be cold if you

made the syrup ahead of time you can heat it up a 
little bit and then you want to you know protect

it a little bit from heat loss if you're making 
a lot of rice it's not as big of an issue because

a large amount of rice stays hot for a long time 
but if you're only making a small amount it cools

down fast so you want to help it along whenever 
you can so let this sit for 20 minutes and then

we're going to come back and give it a stir and 
20 minutes later we are going to flip our rice

over so I've got this rice see how it's gotten all 
the liquid is mostly been absorbed we're going to

give it a stir so I'm just going to do it a kind 
of like a folding motion where I fold the bottom

up because what we're trying to do is get all the 
rice that was earlier at the bottom to come on top

cover it for another 20 minutes or so so at this 
point it's ready - after 20 minutes it'll be ready

to eat so if you do this ahead of time just leave 
it until you're ready to serve this will lacet

room temperature pretty much all day if you're 
going to serve it tomorrow you want to put it in

the fridge but if you make this in the morning 
you want to serve it in the evening just leave

it there it'll be just fine at this point I want 
to talk about the last and final component of the

dessert the crispy toasted mung beans now these 
are mung beans they are green on the outside and

yellow on the inside and these have been shelled 
and split and basically they're going to add a

nice crunch element to the dessert it's optional 
some people don't put them on but I think because

the rice is soft and the mango is soft adding 
the crunchy stuff on top gives a nice textural

variety so I like to add them and basically all 
you have to do is cook them and then toast them

you can cook the beans as many ways to cook these 
beans so I'm going to share with you the way that

I think is easiest and gives the most consistent 
results rinse the beans a couple of times and

cover it with two cups of cold water let the beans 
slowly come to a boil over medium heat we want to

use gradual heat so we have even done this all 
throughout the beans as soon as the water comes

to a boil remove from heat cover and let them sit 
in this hot water for another 10 minutes pour off

the cooking water and rinse off the excess starch 
with cold water this will prevent the beans from

sticking to the pan when they toast let them dry 
off a bit to toast the beans add them to a lightly

greased saute pan and toast them over medium-high 
heat in the beginning they're going to be soft so

be gentle with them when you stir once they turn 
slightly golden brown they are done this should

take about seven to eight minutes spread them out 
while they're cooling so they don't trap any steam

and there is your crunchy munchy mung beans and 
it's eating time well almost so I've got my mango

here I'll cut up into thin pieces now you've seen 
me done this before in the previous video and I

just think it's a nice decorative way to present 
the mango you can cut it into bite-sized pieces

if you want but if you do them thinly you can then 
go and play with it into all sorts of ways and be

artistic and then fill a large plate with a small 
amount of food and make it look all fancy and all

that stuff okay so I've got that and then we've 
got our rice so that it's sort of always should

show you what the rice looks like in the end just 
like that okay so it's there's no more sort of

soupy bits it's all come together I'm rushing this 
a little bit it could sit a little bit longer but

that's okay our coconut sauce salted coconut sauce 
is going on top mmm and then our mung beans going

on top how cute is that now that is a dessert 
to impress however I did say in the beginning

that if you don't have any good fresh mango you 
can still enjoy the stitch and here's how you can

also use a frozen mango now I know what you're 
thinking you're thinking but but but but frozen

mango is all soft and mushy when you thaw it and 
it is and if I serve six with thawed frozen mango

it wouldn't be very appetizing but if I said I'm 
going to serve you sweet sticky rice with a mango

compote aha that done looks so bad now does it 
this one I made using frozen mango and it looks

beautiful and it's just as delicious and its food 
is all about expectation right if you tell people

that you're serving a mango compote all of a 
sudden with mushy is exactly what they're supposed

to be so let me just run through quickly how I 
arrived at this cut the mango into nice cubes and

let them thaw make a syrup from water and palm 
sugar how sweet it needs to be depends on how

sweet your mango is if your mango is on the sour 
side add a pinch of salt my mango strangely lacked

acidity so I added a bit of lime let it marinate 
for half an hour in the fridge when ready to

serve stir in some chopped mint serve the mango 
without the extra syrup in a pretty glassware

and that's it look how cute is that so that's 
all I've got for you today mango and sticky

rice are cono more for the recipe written recipe 
you can visit hot Thai Kitchen.com if you enjoy

the show please click to subscribe and I will 
see you next time for your next delicious tiny
